case_title: MUHAMMAD IBRAHIM vs Mst. SURRAYA SULTANA
reference_no_or_id: Second Appeal from Order No. 589 of 1965
complaint_summary: Mst. Surraya Sultana filed petitions under section 13 of the West Pakistan Urban Rent Restriction Ordinance of 1959 seeking ejectment of tenants occupying portions of her premises, citing intentions to demolish and reconstruct the building.
investigation_summary: The petitioner obtained necessary sanctions from the Municipal Corporation for reconstruction but failed to secure permission from the Rent Controller for converting the residential building into a non-residential one as required under section 11 of the Ordinance.
judgment_summary: The court dismissed the appeals, holding that contravention of section 11 of the Ordinance does not constitute a valid ground for resisting eviction under section 13. The court also found no merit in the appellants' arguments regarding discrepancies in site plans and allegations of default in rent payment.
legal_arguments: Contravention of section 11 does not invalidate eviction petitions under section 13.
Site plan discrepancies were deemed inadmissible under section 63 of the Evidence Act.
Default in rent payment was not sufficiently argued before the lower appellate authority.
statutes: West Pakistan Urban Rent Restriction Ordinance of 1959

witness_statement.Inspector: No objections were raised regarding the mode of proof of the site plan (Exh. P. 1).

appeal_number: Second Appeal from Order No. 589 of 1965
key_issues: Whether contravention of section 11 invalidates eviction petitions under section 13.
Admissibility of site plan discrepancies under section 63 of the Evidence Act.

key_findings.conversion_issue: The contravention of section 11 does not constitute a valid ground for resisting eviction under section 13 of the Ordinance.
key_findings.default_issue: No arguments were raised before the lower appellate authority regarding default in payment of rent.
key_findings.site_plan_issue: The site plan (Exh. P. 1) was deemed admissible as it was a mechanically prepared copy ensuring accuracy.

maxims.Interpretation of statutes: Entire statute must be considered to reconcile provisions and avoid rendering any part insignificant.

legal_terms.Non-residential building: Defined under section 2(d) of the Ordinance as a building used solely for business or trade purposes.
legal_terms.Residential building: Defined under section 2(g) of the Ordinance as a building not classified as non-residential.

words_and_phrases.May: Indicates discretion granted to the Controller under section 13(2).
words_and_phrases.Shall: Indicates mandatory provisions within the Ordinance.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around eviction petitions filed by Mst. Surraya Sultana under section 13 of the West Pakistan Urban Rent Restriction Ordinance of 1959. The appeals were dismissed as contravention of section 11 was not deemed a valid ground for resisting eviction. Arguments regarding site plan discrepancies and rent payment defaults were also rejected.
summary: The appeals were dismissed as the contravention of section 11 of the West Pakistan Urban Rent Restriction Ordinance of 1959 does not provide a valid ground for resisting eviction under section 13. The court found no merit in the arguments regarding default in payment of rent or the admissibility of the site plan. The parties were directed to bear their own costs.
